review_title: Catty people; low expectations; poor management; hypocritical
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bronx, NY
pros: Free tuition for yourself, spouse and kids is becoming very rare. Summer Fridays off (in addition to tons of other paid time off). A lot of really nice people; great support staff; and nice students and faculty. Most people leave at exactly 5pm. Some of the people are very sincere about helping students.
cons: Hard to succeed unless your are a devout Catholic. Really unprofessional and backward in many ways. In some departments, customer service is so poor that people don't look up from their desks (where they are probably doing online shopping or playing on Facebook all day) when you come to ask them a question. The payroll department doesn't even pick up the phone when you call. There is a lot of tolerance for people who are back-biting and catty; there is poor management and systems; and some of the practices certain people pursue are borderline unethical. A lot of people are slackers and hardly do their jobs; and there seems to be no way to fire them. Others work their tails off with no recognition.

job_title: Student Worker in Bronx, NY
pros: Media Services at Rose Hill is run by a superb team who knows how to manage students well. They are knowledgeable, good teachers, and patient.
cons:
Life as a student worker isn't too demanding and the job is easy to get a hang of. Unfortunately, you do have to deal with people who cannot seem to learn how basic technology works. I'm talking about professors. Paid scholars - who don't know how to load powerpoints or do basic troubleshooting. And in some cases, no matter how many times a concept is explained to them, they cannot learn it. 

Other than the few bad apples among our university "clients" I would say the major con is the workload placed on management of Media services. I saw people in useless administrative positions doing nothing while the VPs and managers of Media services held the university together on their own.

review_title: Do you want to have a bow of poverty?
job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: If you love to work to serve "Christ" then this is the place for you.  They will not compensate you for all your work regardless of how much time you put in.  So you will have to be doing the work for "God" other than that they will not pay you extra. Also because no females can be Jesuits, they tend not to promote them either.  There are a lot of irregularities at Fordham University. Such as within the same department somebody will be working 50-60 hours and others work 35 hours.  Is that really fair?
cons: Fordham University is definitely the lowest paying College or University in the Tri-State area.  You can easily look this up.  But unfortunately this University expects you to do more but not expect you to be paid for it.  You will work a lot of weekends like Labor Day weekend, Memorial Day weekend and not be paid or given any additional vacation days for it.  The Dental Benefits is horrible.

job_title: Director of Admissions in Bronx, NY
pros: Flexible schedule, generous time off (vacation/sick leave), overall good working environment, Catholic faith and mission enhances day to day work life experience
cons: Little opportunity to advance, low salary (compared to other universities in the area), poor maternity leave policy (only 6 weeks/8 weeks for c-section - as a Catholic university you would expect better support for mothers)

job_title: Building Assistant in Bronx, NY
pros: At the Office for Student Involvement, it really is the heart of all student activities on campus. It's always busy in some way because of all of the events that are happening on campus. In terms of my work, all of my coworkers are amazing, including the full-time office staff. The job (building assistant) is easy if you know what you are doing with the event set ups.
cons: The only con I have about working as a Building Assistant is that some of the other Building Assistants don't always do their share of the work. They are too busy on the computer looking at Facebook posts instead of copying something or taking down an event space.

job_title: Academic Administrator in Bronx, NY
pros: Collegial atmosphere, Jesuit philosophy of education strongly immersed in university culture:  Educating men and women "in the service of others" and emphasis on "cura personalis" or care of the whole person; University values long-term employees and encourages employees' educational advancement with tuition reimbursement and schedule accommodations; striving to advance academic performance and educational ranking and maintain mission of outreach to the local, underserved and immigrant communities; rewarding involvement with students at every level and age-range.
cons: Silos:  each college and departments within a college are self-contained and very difficult to bridge to create collaboration on larger projects and goals

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
The Lincoln Center location is in a great location. You are convenient to everything. Most the of the main subway lines runs through the city. 

There are some great, caring people at Fordham. Most of the entry level administrators and staff are great. Security are great people as well. 

Great work/life balance if you make it a priority yourself. Don't expect everyone to be okay with that though.
cons:
Upper level staff are not very supportive. It is a good ole boys club. I did not feel like the staff there was very interested in developing me as an employee. Not a place for those looking to develop as young professionals. 

Pay is the lowest in the city, much lower than most others.

review_title: Heartbreak and Disillusionment at my Alma Mater
job_title: Library Clerical in Bronx, NY
pros: Beautiful Campus that is unfortunately situated in the high-crime area of the Bronx. Union prevents unjust firing of clerical staff but is also the ire of all non union employees. Paid holidays, but pay is so poor that it isn't a perk. Health benefits are good but retirement benefit is non-existent - at least for clerical staff.
cons: Maladjusted administration in library. Misanthropic environment. Clerical staff are treated like subhumans. Librarians are regarded as secretaries by university administration and faculty. I loved being a student here, but working in the library has been a nightmare. Fordham Libraries are very, very backwards. Fordham as a whole is in financial trouble and they see the library as the place to cut corners and save money. Cronyism is rampant. Other than hiring cronies, "hiring freezes" prevent upward movement. Pay is awful for library staff while pay for faculty is at 88th percentile nationally.

review_title: It depends which dept you work for.
job_title: Program Advisor in Bronx, NY
pros:
They have great benefits package.  Fordham contributes 11% toward TIAA-CREF after a few years and you can put from 5-11% on your own, which makes for a fantastic retirement plan.

We have a good Associate Director.  He treats his employees very well.
cons:
Our program is small and we are not considered very important to the University.  We ask for assistance all the time due to Federal budget cuts and despite Fordham doing very well financially, they always give us a hard time about giving us money to help us run our program effectively.

Due to issues with our budget, we have not gotten a raise in four years.

review_title: Once a ram, always a ram
job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great community for the most part. I am glad I work in a place open to addressing and recognizing issues with systemic racism within (our) institutions. Great vacation and benefits.
cons: Salary is on the lower end than in other institutions for the same work. Your superiors create the atmosphere. There are some great supervisors and there are others that have high turnover. Also have to know how to navigate your way around and do things the “Fordham” way or you will be met with resistance or simply shut down. Health care costs are rising, health insurance use to cover more and was cheaper. Depending on the job and supervisor work life balance can be tricky. Every department has its own vibe which can lead to silos.

job_title: Research Assistant and Driver in Bronx, NY
pros: Working at Fordham as an intern research assistant was very satisfying. All full time research assistant where thankful that their supervisor are always pushing them to learn more and they all come to love the Jesuit tradition. I also worked as a driver for the Ram Van Department. Policy on attendances and etiquette are fair, and they always see you as a student first, employee second. Greatest decision for a student job.
cons: There is a limit to hours work and overtime is impossible. The new policies established are not fair ( charter runs are given to whoever the operations and assistant manager like - there is no structure in place ).

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: I was an administrator who interacted with many departments, including senior university officials and students.  Great location (Lincoln Center), motivated faculty, high energy student body, interesting academic research, smart people all around make Fordham a stimulating place to work.  Also, excellent benefits and tuition remission could make this a good career stop for someone earning a masters or putting their children through college.
cons: Compensation could be more competitive.  Growth opportunities could be more available.  I stayed longer than I should have because the setting was terrific, and my manager was highly skilled and willing to share knowledge.

review_title: Great place to work I learned alot in the maintenance and janitorial field.
job_title: Cleaner I in New York, NY
pros:
Benefits so many paid days of in the year if you are part of their union which is 503 Teamsters. Also if you are an employee with over a yer of employment your spouse and children can enroll at Fordham University tuition free.
Pay is great I made 19.05 an hour starting as a custodian they called it Cleaner 1.
cons: Work distribution, overtime was not east to come by, even though as a custodian doing heavy work I noticed the need for a few extra hands to complete certain jobs. Pressure to complete tasks at times was over the top in my opinion, and I think there is a lack of understanding for personal emergencies,

review_title: the good and not so good
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Many holidays off, tuition remission for employees (their children and spouses), NYC location is convenient to travel to and is near major subway stations, good benefits
cons: poor policy implementation, little respect for administrators, not flexible with work schedules, your opinions and suggestions are often listened to but not considered even when you are speaking from experience, poor salary offerings, often doing more for less money or no increase at all

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in New York, NY
pros: Interacting with students who want to learn.

review_title: Low morale, untrustworthy management, pitiful pay
job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Administrators get tuition remission and summer Fridays. As a Jesuit university, there are a lot of holidays. The only reason to work here is the tuition remission.
cons: Pitifully low pay for low- and mid-level administrators. Senior management doesn't seem to have the desire or willingness to help with better pay since their own pay is good. There is extremely distrust of the senior administrator that trickles down to every level. There is zero accountability or acknowledgement of good work, so there is no reason to do good work - it's not like you're getting paid for it.

job_title: IT Analyst in Bronx, NY
pros: Friendly managers and supervisors. Work can be very lax at times especially in the afternoon. You can ask for help from full time employees at any time. You can learn technical, IT, and troubleshooting skills. There are other great student workers to go on to do great things from here.
cons: As a student worker there is no room for career growth. There is probably more work in this student worker job than other jobs.

job_title: Associate Director in Bronx, NY
pros: You get tuition remission after working here for 6 months. Which can be a perk if you'd like to take classes. It can also be extended to immediate family members up to a certain number of credits.
cons:
According to Glassdoor, we are paid in the 20th percentile - despite being one of the most expensive schools for students to attend. 
The US Government suggests employees in the Administrative side are underpaid by $20,000 in comparison to their peers at other Colleges/ Universities.
Upper-level management in Student Affairs has been at the institution for a long time without attending conferences or exploring best practices elsewhere. When it comes time to explore other options, extreme 'research' is required often leaving any actual decisions to already be stale or outdated by the time they are implemented.

job_title: Clerical Staff In Library in Bronx, NY
pros: Health Benefits, access to library resources
cons: horrible pay for librarians, awful administration in the library, petty politics between clerical and administrative staff, many small minded and dishonest people, library admins want to maintain hegemony at all costs, laziness of most library administration, library is not valued at all by the university administration, librarians are not faculty, nor do they publish, nor do they  need a second master's degree - as a result, hardly any of them keep up with library trends or best practices, and are simply coasting through to retirement, President is coasting on successes brought about by predecessor's years of hard work. President's agenda, arrogance, and greed are ruining this university.

review_title: A great organization good at getting in its own way
job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: As important a mission as any organization can have, an institution with character, rich history, a dynamic and energetic president, loyal alumni, motivated students, and an assortment of staff who really care. Ambitious mission and unbeatable location, Fordham seems to have the big things down pat, but here, the devil's in the details ...
cons: Stodgy, incompetent middle management invested in little more than maintaining the status quo. Super-bureaucratic. Environment does not foster innovation or welcome change. Things tend to stay afloat by the incompetent and un-invested's exploitation of a caring, devoted few.

job_title: Solutions Architect in Bronx, NY

job_title: Lab Assistant in Bronx, NY

job_title: Marketing Manager in New York, NY

They offer a generous benefits package with three weeks vacation to start, six summer Fridays, 403B retirement and savings, and tuition remission for yourself as well as your children if they attend the University.
cons: Salary is not competitive or generous but the benefits make up for low salary.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in New York, NY

cons: Working for different Professors as GA means totally different experience. For example, if you are looking for a chance to improve your analytics skill, not all Professors are your right target.

review_title: Great benefits, very political place to work
job_title: Administration in Bronx, NY

review_title: You will get out whatever you put in.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bronx, NY

cons: Prepping and teaching the undergraduate labs feels like a waste of time and talent because it is often overly tedious.

job_title: Research Assistant in West Harrison, NY
pros: I have worked on federally funded grants at Fordham Westchester for ten years (school of social work). The people who work here are terrific. It is a uniquely friendly and supportive environment not only at GSS but throughout the building.
cons: Not a real campus...just one building. Not as exciting as Lincoln Center and fewer opportunities. Payroll is slow...took me a few months to get paid when grant first awarded.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Bronx, NY
pros: Proximity to NYC; beautiful campus; makes it easy to collaborate with colleagues from the WCS Bronx Zoo and the NY Botanical Garden.
cons: Two-year contract considered for renewal every other spring semester. A tenure-track professor ends up investing time and effort in trying to secure a salary instead of applying for grants and doing research. Graduate students are assigned a wavy teaching load many times exceeding 12h/week, making it hard for them to do research (subsequently their output and publication record suffers and they are less competitive in the postdoc market). Opaque administrative decision-making processes.

job_title: in New York, NY

cons: The technology and infrastructure could be improved--it would benefit from a major overhaul to streamline and cut down on the red tape.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Syracuse, NY
pros: The pay was decent ($10/hr) and it more than covered my recreational expenses. The hours were amenable to my schedule, too.
cons: I wish I had more hours and that I was able to take on more skills-based jobs but I'm still thankful for having a pretty easy job with refereeing intramural sports.

review_title: Steady and secure employment.  Slow-moving bureaucratic environment.

review_title: Great Place to learn and grow
